did.abstract: Professor of law at the University of Michigan. Papers include correspondence, course materials, and professional files reflecting his interest in constitutional law, university affairs, and legal questions of religious liberty and church-state relations; and manuscripts of writings, speech and conference files, reprints and copies of articles, and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Professor Kauper and his family. Donor no. 5383

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Paul G. Kauper Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Paul G. Kauper was born in Richmond, Indiana. He earned his undergraduate degree at Earlham College in 1929 and a law degree from the University of Michigan in 1932. After graduating he served a s a research assistant at the Law School until 1934 when he joined the firm of white and Case in New York city as a junior associate. In 1936 he returned to the University of Michigan as an assistant professor and in 1939 was promoted to associate professor.

From 1942 to 1945 he was on leave as attorney for the Pan American Petroleum and Transport company. after his return he was promoted to full professor in 1946. Kauper was named the Henry M. Butzel Professor of Law in May 1965

Kauper was a nationally recognized authority on constitutional, particularly in the areas of civil liberties and church-stale relations. He was an advisor to the Michigan Constitutional Convention of 1961-1962.

scopecontent.p: The Paul G. Kauper his teaching and research as a member of the Law School faculty, professional activities and community service on various commission and committees. Basic biographical information can be found in the Topical File in box 17.

The papers include correspondence, course materials, and professional files reflecting his interest in constitutional law, university affairs, and legal questions of religious liberty and church-state relations; and manuscripts of writings, speech and conference files, reprints and copies of articles, and photographs.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence file is arranged chronologically.
The University course material (box 7-11 and 33-35) include outlines and lecture notes for courses in constitutional law, municipal corporations, property, taxation, and a Church-State seminar.
The series Topical Files is somewhat haphazardly arranged. It includes Law School and general University of Michigan material, files related to his professional activities, and biographical files.

scopecontent.p: The Speech and Writings files (not fully processed) includes file on speaking engagements and professional conferences and manuscripts of Kauper's writings and Book reviews.

The Commissions and Committees series (2 linear ft.) consists of correspondence, reports and other material relating Kauper's public service. Most notable are the Ann Arbor School Board's Special Committee to Study Racial Discrimination in the Public Schools, 1963-1964 and the Michigan State Bar Association, Condemnation Procedure Committee, 1956-1969.

University of Michigan Lutheran Student Association

scopecontent.p: The sound recordings (audiotape and CD) consist of a series of lectures on church-state relations given to a group assembled at the Lutheran student chapel in Ann Arbor, February-April 1963.
The Photographs series includes portraits; and photographs of Kauper and his wife at Heidelberg University, where Kauper received an honorary degree in 1970.
